Award.AwardTitle: Design and Integration of the 21 Tesla (T) Magnet
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award from the Division of Chemistry supports the development of the ion optics instrumentation and the analysis tools for a Fourier Transform Ion Cyclotron Resonance Mass Spectrometer (FTICR-MS) which will operate at the unprecedented magnetic field strength of 21 Tesla (T). Dr. Alan Marshall and his team at the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory will develop advanced technologies for ion sources, ion transmission, ion external accumulation, ICR excitation, detection, and automatic instrument control and data reduction. The design aspects in these areas will be supported by large scale supercomputer simulation (greater than one million ions). This work will not only advance 21 T FTICR-MS technology, but mass spectrometry science in general.

In addition to advancing mass spectrometry science, this project will also have direct and groundbreaking implications in the fields of petroleomics, top-down proteomics, and in the characterization of the structure and behavior of macromolecular complexes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The principal scientific outcome of this grant was the successful completion of the first 21 Tesla Fourier transform ion cyclotron resonance mass spectrometer. The 21 Tesla superconducting magnet (funded by companion award CHE-1016942) was commissioned in July 2014 at the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory in Tallahassee, FL and met or exceeded all specifications. The magnet has been at field for eighteen months with no issues. The mass spectrometer was installed and the first mass spectra were collected in November 2014. The instrument was optimized first for analysis of peptides and proteins, and world record performance was achieved (the results appeared in the Journal of the American Society for Mass Spectrometry in September 2015). Further experiments in protein characterization, marine metabolomics, petroleum analysis, and estuarine dissolved organic matter analysis have been performed and will appear in future publications. The instrument was made available to all qualified scientists as part of the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory User Program on October 1, 2015. We expect the 21 Tesla mass spectrometer to continue to set new standards for mass resolving power and mass accuracy for many years.

This project provided financial support and unique educational opportunities for faculty, postdoctoral research associates and graduate students, which included travel to conferences to disseminate results and learn about recent developments in mass spectrometry technology. We initiated collaboration with Northwestern University to develop optimized methods for advanced protein characterization.

The 21 Tesla superconducting magnet is the first of its kind in many ways. The combination of large bore diameter (123 mm), high spatial homogeneity (5 ppm peak-to-peak variation over a 60 mm diameter by 100 mm long cylinder), and low drift rate (2 ppb/hour) is unique for a 21 Tesla magnet. Further, the cryogenic system features no use of liquid nitrogen and no loss of liquid helium. The mass spectrometer features novel ion traps, ion dissociation, and mass spectrometer construction techniques. The record performance of the mass spectrometer sets new standards for mass resolving power and accurate mass measurement, which will stimulate future
developments in the field of mass spectrometry.


Last Modified: 12/23/2015
Modified by: Alan G Marshall
